Although these were non‐pandemic years, the equine association appears to have been about as strong during major (e.g., European‐wide) epidemics as during more local outbreaks. When the next pandemic appeared (in 1729), equine cases were again seen.
58 It was also noted that older horses and horses that had had influenza in the past were often immune.
59 With better epizootic documentation, and occurring with or without coincident epidemics, it was eventually noted, between 1815 and 1873, that major equine epizootics occurred in almost exact 4‐ year cycles,
60 presumably reflecting equine birth cohort susceptibility. Moreover, it came to be understood that although human non‐pandemic influenza in this era was often a seasonal (winter) event, when epidemics were associated with equine epizootics they tended to occur in the spring or fall, the usual seasons in which equine influenza prevailed. Conceivably, during the warmer months horses and humans alike were more likely to be traveling and moving about in agricultural work, and thereby more likely to acquire and transmit influenza.
